# The Associates Looking To Leave Their Biglaw Firms, Like Now
## See you never!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 29, 2022 at 6:32 PMNovember 30, 2022 at 11:05 AM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/the-associates-looking-to-leave-their-biglaw-firms-like-now/&text=The%20Associates%20Looking%20To%20Leave%20Their%20Biglaw%20Firms,%20Like%20Now)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/the-associates-looking-to-leave-their-biglaw-firms-like-now/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/the-associates-looking-to-leave-their-biglaw-firms-like-now/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

According to Above the Law’s New Normal report, what percentage of litigation associates report they are looking to leave their Biglaw firm within the year?

Hint: Less than 20 percent of corporate associate have similar career plans.

See the answer on the next page.

Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. # The Perfect Law Firm For Donald Trump
## This is the law firm of Donald Trump's dreams!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 27, 2016 at 11:48 AMOctober 28, 2016 at 12:52 AM
9
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/the-perfect-law-firm-for-donald-trump/&text=The%20Perfect%20Law%20Firm%20For%20Donald%20Trump)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/the-perfect-law-firm-for-donald-trump/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/the-perfect-law-firm-for-donald-trump/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

President Donald Trump?

Donald Trump, our nation’s Republican nominee for president, seems to have a penchant for threatening to sue others for libel. He is typically represented by bigly big-league Biglaw firms in these endeavors, such as Kasowitz Benson. As you may recall, Kasowitz Benson has stepped in to send letters threatening suit to the New York Times twice in the past month — once for the publication of three pages from [Trump’s 1995 income tax returns](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/donald-trump-chooses-biglaw-firm-to-fight-new-york-times-over-publication-of-tax-documents/), and once for the publication of allegations made by two women that [Trump had sexually assaulted them](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/donald-trumps-biglaw-firm-threatens-to-sue-new-york-times-over-publication-of-sexual-assault-allegations/).

Kasowitz Benson’s representation is all well and good, but perhaps it’s time for Trump to explore an attorney-client relationship with another law firm — one that truly understands him, one that’s willing to “defend[] against baseless charges, such as facts, logic,” and more. At the conclusion of an entertaining segment on Trump’s libel law adventures that was recently featured on [The Daily Show with Trevor Noah](http://www.cc.com/shows/the-daily-show-with-trevor-noah), we meet Jordan Klepper, the man behind the law firm of Trump’s dreams (beginning at 4:59).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The Law Firm of Klepper & Sons is ready to fight for you, Donald J. Trump!


[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is an editor at Above the Law. Feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, or comments. Follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

# Biglaw Firm Reverses Course On Associate Raises, Is Now Onboard With $190,000 Starting Salary
## Better late than never in the associate compensation game.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 26, 2018 at 12:19 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/biglaw-firm-reverses-course-on-associate-raises-is-now-onboard-with-190000-starting-salary/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Reverses%20Course%20On%20Associate%20Raises,%20Is%20Now%20Onboard%20With%20$190,000%20Starting%20Salary)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/biglaw-firm-reverses-course-on-associate-raises-is-now-onboard-with-190000-starting-salary/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/biglaw-firm-reverses-course-on-associate-raises-is-now-onboard-with-190000-starting-salary/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Turns out patience really can be rewarded. The associates at Fish & Richardson were [peeved back in August](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firm-tells-associates-they-can-afford-to-raise-salaries-but-theyre-still-not-going-to/) when the firm announced that a firmwide bump in compensation was simply not in the cards — despite the firm’s boasts that they could, in fact, afford it. Last week, the firm announced that they were reversing course and raises were in the offing.

According to the firm-wide email, the powers that be at Fish “continued to monitor market conditions” and “listened to the reactions of associates throughout the Firm” and whaddaya know, and they’ve “reassessed” their position. Turns out hitting the $190,000 mark for starting associate salaries is good business.

Associates will be paid, effective October 1, on the following scale:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  


 

Fish & Richardson associates may have missed out on three months at these higher salaries (and those fun[ summer bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/biglaw-giant-matches-associate-raises-plus-special-summer-bonuses/) that were all the rage), but better late than never.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises%20Salaries) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises Salaries”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

###Sponsored

From Pilot and Above The Law  
And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. # Up Or Out: The 5 Things You Need To Do To Make Partner
## Becoming a partner is a strenuous but not insurmountable goal; to achieve it, associates must plan for it from the very start.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onSeptember 2, 2016 at 1:28 PMSeptember 2, 2016 at 2:16 PM
5
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/up-or-out-the-5-things-you-need-to-do-to-make-partner/&text=Up%20Or%20Out:%20The%205%20Things%20You%20Need%20To%20Do%20To%20Make%20Partner)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/up-or-out-the-5-things-you-need-to-do-to-make-partner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/up-or-out-the-5-things-you-need-to-do-to-make-partner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Michael Allen

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s](http://laterallink.com/) team of expert contributors. [Michael Allen](http://www.laterallink.com/about/team/1) is Managing Principal at Lateral Link, focusing exclusively on partner placements with Am Law 200 clients and placements for in-house attorneys.
Over the last 15 years, law firm leverage – the ratio between equity partners and all other attorneys – has increased every year, bar two. During this period, the number of equity partners has increased by 27 percent while the number of “all other attorneys” has increased by nearly 86 percent. This trend has tilted leverage to a new high of 3.122 – up 47 percent from 2.13 in 2000. Consequently, it’s never been harder to make partner.


These decreasing odds mean that you must decide, from the minute you step in the firm, what your career goals are. Making partner is the culmination of 7+ years of planning, not happenstance. So how does one become a partner? Here are five things you must do if you want to make partner.

1. Take a heat check. Peak marketability for associates occurs between their third and fifth year. The vast majority of all our associate openings are for midlevel associates, not junior or senior level. Any earlier than three years, associates won’t have much substantive experience; any later than five years, their runway is quite short if they don’t make partner. Associates should use their most marketable time to determine their odds of making partner at their current firm.

If the prospects for partnership are not good, this is the best time to make a lateral move to a firm where your shot at making partner is higher. Moving during the 3-5 year range allows associates to leverage their desirability to find a firm that puts them on track for making partner, while giving them a long enough runway to accrue the necessary goodwill and experience to cash in for a partnership in 3-5 years.

How can one determine their odds at making partner?

2. Look at the supply and demand. Firms are businesses that obey simple economic rules like any other business. There are a certain number of partnership positions available for a certain practice area before a firm experiences overcrowding and significant diminishing returns.

To calculate demand, you should look at the current stock of partners. If the partners are young and have a “lifer” mentality, your prospects are poor. If the partnership ranks are skewed older, your chances improve. Lateral moves can complicate this analysis; you can never be certain how long a partner will actually stay. Our calculations have shown most partners jump firms 3-5 years after making their first lateral move – possibly opening a spot when your partnership candidacy is approaching, assuming there is business sitting on the table.

However, demand is not the only variable. Who are your competitors? If your practice is filled with a glut of associates with the same year and similar credentials, the odds decrease. If you are stuck in this predicament, a lateral move is likely your best bet, to find a firm where you stand out relative to your peers, which brings us to our next point.

3. Find a smaller pond. If the supply or demand is not conducive to your partnership odds, consider seeking a firm that is both lower leverage and has more attractive billing rates for you to develop a book. Your competition will be less fierce, and the alternative is possibly staying for a perpetual senior associateship.

4. Find a growing pond. Growing practices are another advantageous environment. This principle operates in tandem with demand. If a firm is significantly growing a practice, they are usually at a disadvantage of demanding more than the market can supply. Moving into a growing practice is not only easier, but chances are, the partnership stock is thin – making your prospects greater in a few years. You will have the institutional memory for the expanding practice, making you even more indispensable.

5. Find the right platform. Not every firm puts an associate up for partnership. Highly leveraged firms often have less specialized work for any particular associate, denying the opportunity to specialize. If you are at one of these firms, and your goal is to make partner, you should be looking for a firm whose structure – supply and demand – and environment – experience and support – maximize your opportunities for becoming a partner.

Becoming a partner is a strenuous but not insurmountable goal. To achieve it, associates must plan for it from the very start. If you are an associate and need advice on how to make partner, feel free to contact my [fellow recruiters](http://laterallink.com/about/team) at Lateral Link.

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [here](http://laterallink.com/about/testimonials) to find out more about us.

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 09.11.17
## * "Legal aid is critical after a natural disaster," so the Florida Bar has raised the income cap for its online legal clinic so Floridians affected by Hurricane Irma can get legal assistance, and the Florida Bar Foundation has set aside $500,000 to support legal aid organizations. How generous! [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/09/08/the-florida-bar-fema-prepare-to-help-hurricane-irma-victims/)] * Sixteen years have passed since the September 11 attacks, but we've yet to try or convict any of the five men who are said to have planned the day that changed America, including Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, the alleged "architect of 9/11." Some lawyers wonder why this "isn't a cause for more outrage." [[Al Jazeera](http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/justice-remains-elusive-911-anniversary-170910123831518.html)] * In case you missed it, Irell & Manella has elected [Ellisen Turner](http://www.irell.com/professionals-Ellisen-Turner.html) as its first African-American managing partner. Among the many accolades he's earned over the course of his illustrious legal career, Above the Law once [referred to him as a "hottie."](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/07/atl-summer-associate-event-contest-the-winner/) Congratulations on all accounts! [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/irell-elects-first-african-american-managing-partner/)] * Lawmakers from both parties are interested in holding hearings on the massive Equifax hack, and after outcry from state attorneys general about an arbitration clause that would have prevented those affected by the data breach from suing, the credit reporting agency has changed its terms of service. [[The Hill](http://thehill.com/policy/technology/349878-mass-outrage-over-equifax-breach)] * In the wake of Justice Scalia's death, Justice Kagan says the remaining justices did everything they could to avoid 4-4 split decisions: "[W]e all made a very serious effort to try to find common ground even where we thought we couldn’t. It sort of forced us to keep talking to each other." [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel](http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2017/09/08/justice-elena-kagan-says-court-had-reach-more-consensus-after-antonin-scalias-death/646125001/)] * Which Biglaw firm is about to get a lot bigger? It's Cozen O'Connor, apparently. According to CEO Michael Heller, he'd like to increase the firm's head count to somewhere between 700 and 1,000 lawyers in the next five years. About 600 attorneys are currently working at Cozen. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202797621696/Cozen-OConnor-CEO-Says-Firms-Growth-Has-Just-Begun?mcode=1202615731542&curindex=2&curpage=ALL)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 11, 2017 at 8:47 AMSeptember 10, 2017 at 7:53 PM
1

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# More Good News From Biglaw Firms Not Cutting Back
## Some firms are staying the course.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 29, 2020 at 3:15 PMMay 1, 2020 at 4:02 PM
37
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/more-good-news-from-biglaw-firms-not-cutting-back/&text=More%20Good%20News%20From%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Not%20Cutting%20Back)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/more-good-news-from-biglaw-firms-not-cutting-back/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/more-good-news-from-biglaw-firms-not-cutting-back/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s been a few weeks since we did [a roundup of firms that aren’t implementing austerity measures](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/the-biglaw-firms-rolling-out-good-news-for-now/) and with bad news dominating our coverage, we thought it was time to remind everyone out there that not every firm finds themselves struggling during the downturn. Frankly, we don’t get enough of these stories, so if your firm has issued a note of reassurance, let us know [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Good%20News) so we can acknowledge the firms that weren’t living on the knife’s edge of margins. We’ll be updating this piece as we see stuff.

Covington & Burling: The firm sent out a video explaining that there are no current plans to conduct either layoffs or compensation cuts to attorneys or staff and that the firm is well-positioned to weather an economic downturn. The message went further and reminded everyone that the firm didn’t need to perform any cutbacks during the last financial crisis, bolstering its credibility on this point.

Sidley: The firm was early on the work-from-home train and carried that over to resisting austerity measures. No layoffs or cuts on the horizon at this point. Additionally, the firm says it will pay summer associates for the number of weeks they agreed to work at Sidley and continue to offer a summer program even if it has to be online.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Greenberg Traurig: Reports are that the firm is offering a good deal of transparency about the firm’s financial position and have assured attorneys that they will not lay off people there has been no word about salary cuts at this point. Greenberg Traurig got flack for not raising salaries in the past despite strong profitability numbers, but that also means the firm wasn’t operating on thin margins and can absorb the current hit.

Arnold & Porter: Oops. We forgot about Arnold & Porter. From [National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/04/17/arnold-porter-resists-pay-cuts-as-covid-19-crisis-follows-revenue-dip/):

No large cost-cutting measures at Arnold & Porter have been publicly reported. The Am Law 50 firm’s chairman, Richard Alexander, said in a statement it has “not announced any changes to our staffing levels or compensation.” A spokeswoman confirmed late in the week that no furloughs, layoffs or compensation cuts had been made among staff and attorneys, and there had been no reductions in partner draws or distributions.

Shearman: The firm informed everyone at the beginning of April that the partnership is not planning on cutting salaries or placing any staff/attorneys on furlough. This is made possible by the [voluntary leave program](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/shearman-sterling-rolls-out-covid-19-austerity-measures/), which is an “austerity measure” but one that’s designed to keep other cuts from happening, so there’s that.

# This Law Firm Invited Everyone To Work From Portugal And I Guarantee They Have A Better 'Firm Culture' For It
## Vela Wood's VW Abroad program should inspire more firms.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 9, 2022 at 12:12 PMSeptember 9, 2022 at 11:34 AM
30
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/this-law-firm-invited-everyone-to-work-from-portugal-and-i-guarantee-they-have-a-better-firm-culture-for-it/&text=This%20Law%20Firm%20Invited%20Everyone%20To%20Work%20From%20Portugal%20And%20I%20Guarantee%20They%20Have%20A%20Better%20‘Firm%20Culture’%20For%20It)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/this-law-firm-invited-everyone-to-work-from-portugal-and-i-guarantee-they-have-a-better-firm-culture-for-it/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/this-law-firm-invited-everyone-to-work-from-portugal-and-i-guarantee-they-have-a-better-firm-culture-for-it/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Better than your office.

For Biglaw firms trying to figure out how to entice associates back to the office, have you ever considered moving the whole firm to an amazing locale for a few weeks? Because one firm spent the summer in Lisbon, Portugal.

Texas-based boutique [Vela Wood](https://velawoodlaw.com/) previously established a “[Desk Independence](https://velawoodlaw.com/global-reach/)” program, allowing employees to take a month to work from anywhere. Fueled by the success of that program, the firm took it up a notch this summer with the VW Abroad program, offering the opportunity for the team to decamp to Portugal from July 10, 2022 to August 6, 2022. Folks could head to over for two to four weeks and the firm [offered a stipend](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/this-firm-is-planning-the-ultimate-workcation-trip-abroad-for-employees/) to defray the costs for employees and their families.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
This is very much in line with the Vela Wood philosophy of travel, summed up by managing partner Kevin Vela, “We believe that travel helps people become better global citizens. And we think with that comes understand, comes awareness, and comes self actualization.” This commitment to travel formed the basis of this video highlighting the firm as a [Clio](https://www.clio.com/) customer (and obviously highlighting Clio’s ability to facilitate this model).


So bringing folks together abroad was a logical move. And the firm got a great response per a memo sent earlier in the summer:

So far, over 20 employees are participating – approximately 50% of the firm’s employees. Many are bringing their spouses, partners, parents, and kids of all ages to bring the total number to more than 50 individuals. The firm has also invited clients to meet the team in Lisbon this summer. Vela Wood plans to host weekly events with members of the local startup community as it seeks to foster entrepreneurship around the world.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
And it doubled as an opportunity to build business. Perfect all around trip.

Unsurprisingly, Vela Wood sees this as the first of many VW Abroad programs.

Not every firm is going to be able to do something like this, but whenever a firm complains about lawyers not showing up to the office, the justification is usually some song and dance about “building firm culture.” If that’s the purpose, consider sending a team or department to some cool, new location for a week or two. They’ll come out the other side more united from working in unfamiliar surroundings than their entrenched offices.

Not for nothing, a firm is much more likely to get people to come in on a random Wednesday when they know they’re going to see the folks they bonded with for two weeks in Prague or whatever.

Unless all that big firm talk about “office culture” is just a pretense to cover deep insecurities over feeling a loss of control… but I’m sure it’s not that.

# Biglaw Partners' Satisfaction With Their Pay 'Remains Robust'
## Only a tiny percentage of partners are 'very dissatisfied' with their pay.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 20, 2022 at 3:45 PMOctober 20, 2022 at 3:37 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/biglaw-partners-satisfaction-with-their-pay-remains-robust/&text=Biglaw%20Partners’%20Satisfaction%20With%20Their%20Pay%20‘Remains%20Robust’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/biglaw-partners-satisfaction-with-their-pay-remains-robust/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/biglaw-partners-satisfaction-with-their-pay-remains-robust/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Attorneys make a lot of money in [Biglaw]. And I think they’re well aware of that, and for the most part, feel good about it.

— [Karen Andersen](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/karen-andersen?byconsultantorauthor=karen-andersen), a partner in Major, Lindsey & Africa’s partner practice, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/10/19/partner-pay-is-up-but-pronounced-differences-remain-between-cities/), concerning MLA’s biannual [Partner Compensation Survey](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/insights/research/2022-partner-compensation-survey), which was published earlier this week. Overall, partner pay is up, but compensation differences across cities “continues to be pronounced.” When it comes to partners’ satisfaction with their salaries, around 29% of respondents said they were “very satisfied” with their pay, while 35% said they were “moderately satisfied,” and 11% said they were “slightly satisfied.” (Compare these numbers with the partners who weren’t as happy with their pay: about 8% said they were “slightly dissatisfied,” 6% said they were “moderately dissatisfied,” and 4% said they were “very dissatisfied.” Six percent of Biglaw partners surveyed were “neutral” as to their pay satisfaction.)

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Am Law 200 Firm Reduces Partner Distributions In Response To Coronavirus Crisis
## Hopefully the firm won't have to cut anyone else's salaries.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 8, 2020 at 11:11 AMApril 8, 2020 at 3:12 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-200-firm-reduces-partner-draws-in-response-to-coronavirus-crisis/&text=Am%20Law%20200%20Firm%20Reduces%20Partner%20Distributions%20In%20Response%20To%20Coronavirus%20Crisis)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-200-firm-reduces-partner-draws-in-response-to-coronavirus-crisis/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-200-firm-reduces-partner-draws-in-response-to-coronavirus-crisis/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Earlier this month, we reported that it was only a matter of time before more Biglaw partners would be forced to cut their draws and distributions to stave off the pain caused by the novel coronavirus. In fact, law firm management consultant Patrick McKenna said he’d be surprised if [at least 80 percent of the top 200 firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/more-biglaw-firms-to-cut-partner-draws-before-resorting-to-layoffs-furloughs/) in the country hadn’t made such a move by the middle of April, noting that “a typical reduction is in the range of 30 percent.” We’ve got to give him a lot of credit, because his prediction continues to ring true.

Today, we have news on a firm ranked just outside of the Am Law 100 that’s decided to make a move on partner compensation for the benefit of all its employees.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
A confidential source tells us that Lowenstein Sandler is slashing its partner distributions so the firm can safely ride out the COVID-19 financial roller coaster that’s soon to come. Here are the details that we received:

At a video town hall meeting attended by over 500 employees last Friday, Lowenstein Sandler Chair Gary Wingens announced that the firm had a very strong March, yet had substantially reduced distributions to its equity partners in order to preserve liquidity for what it expected to be a bumpy second quarter. While he hoped to not have to make other cuts, Wingens made it clear that they were watching their metrics very carefully over the coming weeks.

When reached for comment by Above the Law, firm management confirmed Wingens’s comments, but did not specify the percentage cuts partners were taking. We hope this move is enough to guide the firm through what’s sure to be a rough time.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

# Judge To Register As Sex Offender After Pleading Guilty To Stealing Panties
## The admitted serial panty thief has been suspended from the bench.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 18, 2019 at 11:43 AMSeptember 18, 2019 at 10:50 AM
33
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/judge-to-register-as-sex-offender-after-pleading-guilty-to-stealing-panties/&text=Judge%20To%20Register%20As%20Sex%20Offender%20After%20Pleading%20Guilty%20To%20Stealing%20Panties)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/judge-to-register-as-sex-offender-after-pleading-guilty-to-stealing-panties/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/judge-to-register-as-sex-offender-after-pleading-guilty-to-stealing-panties/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Next time a judge asks to review your briefs, keep in mind that he may mean it quite literally.

In March 2018, Suffolk County District Judge Robert Cicale was arrested after breaking into a former intern’s home, rummaging through her hamper, and stealing a pair of her panties. At the time of his arrest, the judge was found with other [“soiled female undergarments”](https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Judge-Underwear-Thief-Home-Robert-Cicale-Arrest-New-York-478405363.html) in his pockets, “from other times [he] went into the house.” Cicale was charged with second-degree burglary and pleaded not guilty, despite having already admitted that he’d stolen the panties. He was immediately placed on leave suspended from the bench (with pay, of course).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Late last week, Cicale pleaded guilty to a lesser felony charge of second-degree attempted burglary. According to District Attorney Timothy Sini, considering the fact that Cicale “violated the law, the public’s trust and the victims’ sense of security,” the disrobed judge’s guilty plea “holds him accountable for his actions and serves justice.”

Cicale’s attorney says his client is a new man. [Newsday](https://www.newsday.com/long-island/crime/robert-cicale-pleaded-guilty-panties-1.36282106) has additional details:

“Judge Cicale accepted responsibility for his actions today,” [Michael J.] Brown said. “He has served the people of Suffolk County honorably for the last 26 years, as a Legal Aid attorney, Town of Islip attorney and a district court judge. He has dealt with his mental illness issues in a proactive manner and is a better person for doing so.”

Cicale will be sentenced November 15, and it’s expected that he will receive five years of probation under which he’ll have to register as a sex offender.

# What Will It Take For Federal Judges To Expand Their Clerkship Hiring Pool?
## This would be a good opportunity for all federal judges to at least consider hiring graduates of other law schools outside of the usual suspects.
By [Steven Chung](https://abovethelaw.com/author/shannonachimalbe/)  
onOctober 12, 2022 at 11:18 AMOctober 12, 2022 at 10:40 AM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/what-will-it-take-for-federal-judges-to-expand-their-clerkship-hiring-pool/&text=What%20Will%20It%20Take%20For%20Federal%20Judges%20To%20Expand%20Their%20Clerkship%20Hiring%20Pool?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/what-will-it-take-for-federal-judges-to-expand-their-clerkship-hiring-pool/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/what-will-it-take-for-federal-judges-to-expand-their-clerkship-hiring-pool/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

I have been hearing that certain federal judges will [stop hiring graduates](https://davidlat.substack.com/p/a-prominent-federal-judge-declares) of a name-brand law school whose alumni include trial judge extraordinaire [Chamberlain Haller](https://www.abajournal.com/gallery/favorite_movie_television_judges/1500). I am not going to discuss the events that led to this although I will suggest that if the dean wants to get back in these judges’ good graces, she must publicly use the raw power of her position to effectively and immediately put the house back in order.

Time will tell as to whether this will change the status quo, particularly since a feeder judge has not (at least not openly) announced a similar ban. But this would be a good opportunity for all federal judges to at least consider hiring graduates of other law schools outside of the usual suspects.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The hiring process for clerkships is complicated. I think it is safe to assume that every federal judge has more clerkship applications than they know what do to with. As a result, they can be selective about who to interview, even if it means excluding most law schools. On the other hand, the candidates they are seriously considering are probably going to be considered by other judges as well. So some federal judges will have to negotiate and wait while applicants consider their options. In the end, they may not hire their first or second choice.

A good number of federal judges want to be (or continue to be) feeder judges with records of sending their clerks to the Supreme Court. Being a feeder judge has its advantages, such as avoiding the hiring hassle described above. They will get more applications from highly talented applicants who want a Supreme Court clerkship. Also, they have a far better chance of hiring the people they want. In addition, being known as a feeder judge sets them apart from their colleagues and gives the impression that they are going places.

It seems like there are two ways to change the system. The first is to change the hiring process and, more importantly, the hiring culture. I do not think that judges should punish an entire law school by not hiring its graduates. Instead, judges should be encouraged, praised, and rewarded for giving underdog candidates a chance. For some reason, this is seen as a risk.

Those who don’t care about being a feeder judge are probably in the best position to widen the hiring net. Of course, they are still going to hire only the top students who come with demonstrated research and writing skills along with exemplary faculty recommendations. They will not likely get a clerkship at the high court, but at least they get a biglaw job as a consolation prize.

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

From Pilot and Above The Law  
But what about feeder judges who may have [supreme ambitions](https://www.amazon.com/Supreme-Ambitions-David-Lat/dp/1627220461)? Is it worth it to give a solid candidate from an average law school an unprecedented clerkship opportunity if it means possibly lowering the chances that the Supreme Court will hire your clerks? Those who go with the status quo might rationalize their decisions by stating that they will make changes when they become a justice. Looking at the current track records, the odds of that happening seem low.

The other way to disrupt the clerkship hiring process is to appoint and confirm judges who will hire clerks from a broader range of schools. The president should nominate a graduate of a nonelite school if politically feasible. During the confirmation hearings, Senate judiciary committee members should get a promise from the nominee that he or she will hire at least one clerk from a nonelite school on a regular basis. This should start at the Supreme Court level so that judges from district and circuit courts can cater to each justice’s personal preferences in order to increase their chances of getting the coveted feeder status.

The late Chief Justice Rehnquist only hired three law clerks every term. And one of them came from a law school that isn’t from the usual 14. But no one has followed his example. I suppose that fear, loyalty, and even snobbery could be involved. It should not take a controversy for a judge to consider other law schools for clerkship opportunities.

Steven Chung is a tax attorney in Los Angeles, California. He helps people with basic tax planning and resolve tax disputes. He is also sympathetic to people with large student loans. # A Step Backwards For Financial Transparency In Biglaw
## A leader in transparency falls back into the pack.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onAugust 15, 2017 at 7:54 PMAugust 15, 2017 at 5:11 PM
18
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/a-step-backwards-for-financial-transparency-in-biglaw/&text=A%20Step%20Backwards%20For%20Financial%20Transparency%20In%20Biglaw)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/a-step-backwards-for-financial-transparency-in-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/a-step-backwards-for-financial-transparency-in-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Closing the gates on financial disclosure?

In the legal world, as well as the world more generally, the trend is in favor of transparency. Technological advances, including but not limited to social media, make it much easier to share information — and much harder to hide it.

Here at Above the Law, we help bring greater transparency to the often opaque legal profession. This enables lawyers and law students to make more informed decisions about their legal careers and their lives.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
But the move towards transparency does not proceed uninterrupted. A few steps forward are sometimes followed by a step backward. For example, the ABA is thinking about requiring [less rather than more disclosure](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/first-monday-musings-by-dean-vik-amar-a-guided-tour-through-the-debate-over-changing-the-aba-employment-data-form/) from law schools when it comes to graduates’ employment outcomes (a move that it’s currently [reconsidering](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/08/14/aba-will-reconsider-recent-change-to-way-it-counts-law-grad-jobs/), after significant [criticism and public outcry](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/aba-takes-giant-step-backwards-on-transparency/)).

A similar development is happening in the world of Biglaw: [K&L Gates](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/kl-gates/), a firm that has long prided itself on financial transparency, is now moving in the opposite direction. After four consecutive years of [publicly posting its financial statements](http://www.klgates.com/aboutus/financials/), the firm has closed the gates on such disclosure.

An observant reader pointed out to me that K&L Gates posted its 2015 financials in March 2016, along with a [press release](http://www.klgates.com/files/Upload/2015_Firm_Financials.pdf). For 2017, we’re now in August, and the firm has yet to post its 2016 financials.

And don’t expect it to post them — ever. We reached out to the firm, which responded through a spokesperson: “K&L Gates did not issue a press release with its financial results for the 2016 financial year, and instead provided financial results for the year directly to Am Law.”

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
But sharing financial information with Am Law is not the same thing as sharing it with the public — including firm clients, employees, and recruits. The Am Law 100 rankings contain only specific pieces of information, such as revenue per lawyer and profits per equity partner, and do not offer the comprehensive picture of a firm’s financial health that full financial statements do.

Why did K&L Gates previously disclose its financials? Here’s its explanation, from the firm website page entitled [“Our Financial Transparency”](http://www.klgates.com/aboutus/financials/):

At K&L Gates, we believe that open and honest communication regarding a law firm’s financial health is an essential part of building strong and durable relationships with clients.

In an effort to achieve greater transparency, in 2013 our global law firm voluntarily disclosed a detailed account of the firm’s 2012 financial results, a first among U.S.-based law firms. In keeping with our commitment to release this information on an annual basis, we repeated this disclosure for the next three years. This dedication has led our firm to possess one of the most transparent business models of any law firm in the world.

Whoops, scratch that! During the time that I was writing this story, the firm took down the “Our Financial Transparency” page. Not so transparent! (But you can see what the page used to look like via [Archive.org](http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.klgates.com/aboutus/financials/).)

Was K&L Gates’s move away from “open and honest communication” driven by a desire to hide bad news? The firm conducted [significant layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/nationwide-layoff-watch-150-to-200-jobs-is-a-lot-of-jobs/) in [February 2017](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/nationwide-layoff-watch-banished-beyond-the-gates/), which is never a good sign, and suffered [high-profile partner departures](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/why-are-so-many-partners-walking-out-the-kl-gates/) in 2016. But when you look at the firm’s financial results as reported in Am Law, K&L Gates actually had a fairly good 2016: revenue [grew by almost 11 percent](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202784880457/Pa-Firms-See-Mixed-Fortunes-in-2017-Am-Law-100-Rankings?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL), revenue per lawyer grew by 13 percent, and profits per partner [grew by 17 percent](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202784617547), breaking the $1 million mark.

From Pilot and Above The Law

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
It’s worth noting, however, that future years might not be so golden for K&L Gates. Its 2016 results were helped by a large, one-time contingency fee award of [$210 million](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/good-news-out-of-the-kl-gates/). So perhaps it was smart to cut back on disclosure this year, despite a strong 2016, in anticipation of an ugly 2017 (and maybe beyond).

And here’s another possibility: perhaps reduced transparency is part of the post-[Peter Kalis](http://www.klgates.com/peter-j-kalis/) era. The iconic Biglaw leader ended his two-decade tenure as leader of K&L Gates this past February, and he was a driving force behind the firm’s transparency. Check out this YouTube video of Kalis (while you still can), [The Importance of Transparency](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEXWQw6fmyY), or read this great [2012 memo of his](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/09/everything-is-great-kl-states-peter-kalis-comes-out-swinging/), in which he shut down negative rumors about K&L Gates with detailed data about firm finances.

It seems that [Kalis’s successors](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/it-takes-two-to-fill-the-shoes-of-peter-kalis-at-kl-gates/), firm chairman [Michael Caccese](http://www.klgates.com/michael-s-caccese/) and global managing partner [James Segerdahl](http://www.klgates.com/james-r-segerdahl/), don’t share their predecessor’s commitment to candor. Maybe this will be good for K&L Gates — or maybe it won’t. As Justice Louis Brandeis [famously observed](https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Louis_Brandeis), “Sunlight is said to be the best of disinfectants.”

# Lawyers Should Delegate More Nonlegal Work To Nonlawyers
## It is important to create boundaries, and delegate matters to brokers or other professionals who are more qualified to take on a task.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onNovember 12, 2021 at 4:46 PMNovember 12, 2021 at 1:15 PM
35
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/lawyers-should-delegate-more-nonlegal-work-to-nonlawyers/&text=Lawyers%20Should%20Delegate%20More%20Nonlegal%20Work%20To%20Nonlawyers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/lawyers-should-delegate-more-nonlegal-work-to-nonlawyers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/lawyers-should-delegate-more-nonlegal-work-to-nonlawyers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When people attend law school, they have a fairly distorted view of what lawyers actually do on a day-to-day basis. Indeed, when I was in law school, I thought I would spend all of my days in court, kind of like the lawyers I saw on television and in movies. In reality, the practice of law can be pretty boring sometimes, and in many instances, lawyers need to complete nonlegal work that does not require any kind of legal training. In many situations, lawyers should delegate more nonlegal work to nonlawyers so that attorneys can focus on the legal work at hand in a representation.

One of the main reasons why lawyers should give nonlegal tasks to nonlawyers is because other professionals may be better suited to handle certain parts of a representation than a lawyer. Attorneys often need to rely on accountants, private investigators, and other skilled individuals in order to best serve a client, and it is okay to assemble a team so that a client’s interests can be best served during a representation.

For instance, I once had a case in which I had to track down and depose a witness to an incident who moved out of town. I tried my best to hunt this person down on Google, public records searches, and all of the other resources I had available to me, and only after a great deal of effort was I able to track this person down. The next time I had to track someone down like this, I hired a private investigator to complete the leg work for me. The private investigator was able to easily find this person, and it is likely that the private investigator charged less than the billable time I spent on the matter. By using the services of another professional, I likely protected the client’s bottom line and avoided some headache on my end.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
In some situations, lawyers should delegate nonlegal work to nonlawyers to establish boundaries and ensure that they are dealing with matters that are in the purview of legal counsel. Like many attorneys, every so often I will handle a real estate closing. Usually, a variety of professionals are involved with closings, including title people, brokers, banking professionals, and others. Often, clients will ask their attorneys to arrange matters that should properly be handled by brokers, such as scheduling walkthroughs and other on-the-ground information about the property. When I first started handling this line of work, I was much more likely to handle this work myself.

However, it is important to create boundaries, and delegate matters to brokers or other professionals who are more qualified to take on a task during a deal. I am sure many of us did not think we would be arguing about air conditioning cleaning and other matters when we decided to be lawyers, and only certain discreet matters in real estate transactions and other similar matters involve legal issues that should be handled by lawyers. It is important to set boundaries so that a lawyer’s time is not wasted on matters that could be handled by others and ensure that the professional that has the best skill in an area is handling a task.

Even within law firms, lawyers sometimes take it upon themselves to perform nonlegal tasks even though other professionals are available to assist lawyers with this work. This may be because lawyers know that they can bill for the time spent on such administrative tasks to clients, or there is no other work available to more junior lawyers so that more senior lawyers give junior lawyers chores that do not involve legal training in order to pass the time.

For instance, I once worked at a law firm that did not have much legal work for a period to keep the lawyers in our office busy. What ended up happening is that partners started hogging work that should have been performed by senior associates, and senior associates started hogging work that should have been performed by junior associates. As a result, there was little left for junior associates to do other than administrative tasks. During this time, I spent days pulling and printing cases cited in an appellate brief we filed so the partner would have binders of cases with him at oral argument. Of course, these binders were never consulted once. I also did other administrative tasks that a paralegal or a legal secretary could have performed, and probably in a more efficient manner. All the while, our clients were at least partially billed for time that could have been completed by staff that had a much lower billable hour rate.

All told, lawyers often need to complete work that does not require a legal education, but attorneys should minimize such tasks as much as possible. This allows lawyers to be more efficient and bring more value to their clients.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. # Biglaw Firm Makes Monday A Fun Day With Special Bonuses And Salary Increases
## This is a great way to start the week!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 12, 2021 at 1:13 PMJuly 12, 2021 at 2:32 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/kasowitz-raise-2021/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Makes%20Monday%20A%20Fun%20Day%20With%20Special%20Bonuses%20And%20Salary%20Increases)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/kasowitz-raise-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/kasowitz-raise-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If you’re an associate who’s got a major case of the Mondays, there’s nothing that’ll boost your motivation like an announcement that not only will your firm be raising salaries across the board for all associates but it will also be doling out special bonuses (for some).

Kasowitz Benson Torres had a bit of a rough go of it in 2020, having taken out a PPP loan (one which the firm has [not yet disclosed](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/07/08/am-law-firms-get-210-million-in-ppp-loans-forgiven/) if it’s been forgiven), but finished up the year with $219,396,000 gross revenue, landing it in 142nd place in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking. The firm is just now getting around to joining peer firms for special bonuses and commensurate salary increases.

According to a memo sent earlier today, Kasowitz will be moving to a national firm-wide salary scale, and it’s a Davis Polk match. Here’s what it looks like at the firm:



The firm will also be matching the Davis Polk scale for special bonuses, ranging from $12,000 total for the class of 2020 to $64,000 total for the class of 2014 and beyond (plus counsel). These bonuses will be payable in two installments (one in September 2021 and one in January 2022), and apply only to New York attorneys.

As far as we’re concerned, it’s always better late than never when it comes to compensation matters. Congratulations to everyone at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to see the memo from Kasowitz Benson Torres.)

We depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

# Biglaw Firm Does Good In A Big Way: Gibson Dunn Secures Major Win For George Floyd Protester Injured By LAPD Officer
## This is the first time a verdict has been secured against the LAPD arising from the George Floyd protests.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 10, 2023 at 1:13 PMMarch 10, 2023 at 12:00 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/gibson-dunn-major-win-george-floyd-protester-lapd-civil-rights/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Does%20Good%20In%20A%20Big%20Way:%20Gibson%20Dunn%20Secures%20Major%20Win%20For%20George%20Floyd%20Protester%20Injured%20By%20LAPD%20Officer)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/gibson-dunn-major-win-george-floyd-protester-lapd-civil-rights/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/gibson-dunn-major-win-george-floyd-protester-lapd-civil-rights/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Deon Jones (Photo by Robert Smith/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images)

In the wake of George Floyd’s 2020 murder by a police officer, mass protests broke out across the country in response to police brutality and racism. Hundreds upon hundreds of peaceful protestors were injured by police through their use of excessive force during this time. One of them was [Deon Jones](https://twitter.com/deontjones), 31, who works in entertainment and brand consulting in the Los Angeles area. Jones was shot in the face with a rubber bullet by a police officer, sustaining injuries that save for the grace of a few millimeters, could have blinded or even killed him. Thanks to a Biglaw firm’s pro bono representation, Jones just won a first-of-its-kind verdict that may serve as a blueprint for future civil rights cases.

[Gibson Dunn](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/gibson-dunn/), a firm that’s currently ranked at No. 11 on the Am Law 100, took the lead in representing Jones, with lawyers from the firms New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C., offices getting involved to help secure a win. [Orin Snyder](https://www.gibsondunn.com/lawyer/snyder-orin/) — one of the firm’s most senior attorneys, who is widely recognized as one of the country’s leading trial lawyers and litigators — guided the case to a landmark victory. Yesterday, a federal jury determined that LAPD officer Peter Bueno had violated Jones’s civil rights in the shooting, finding Bueno personally liable for Jones’s injuries. Jones was awarded $375,000 ($250,000 in actual damages and $125,000 in punitive damages).

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The [Los Angeles Times](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2023-03-09/jury-protester-injured-by-lapd-projectile) captured Jones’s reaction to the verdict being read:

Jones listened with his head bowed as a judge read the jury’s decision in a Santa Ana courtroom. Afterward, he said it was “a good day.”

“This victory isn’t just mine. It is for all the folks who historically have went out and protested,” Jones said. “It sends a message that … law enforcement cannot brutalize folks.”

“This is the first time anyone has sued and successfully obtained a verdict against the LAPD arising from the 2020 demonstrations,” Snyder said of his client’s victory. “The verdict sends a powerful message that the police cannot trample the constitutional rights of peaceful protesters. We hope the verdict will lead to meaningful reforms in how the police approach demonstrations in the future.” This is not just an exceptionally meaningful win for civil rights advocates in California, but all across the country.

Gibson Dunn’s pro bono representation of Jones in this case is part of the firm’s broader racial justice initiative, reaffirming its commitment to advancing racial justice and equity. In fact, Gibson Dunn’s largest client is its pro bono practice, and last year, the firm did about $135 million in pro bono work for causes and clients that include racial justice, free speech, immigration, LGBTQ rights, women’s rights, and international human rights.

[Katie Marquart](https://www.gibsondunn.com/lawyer/marquart-katie/), Gibson Dunn’s pro bono chair, offered this statement:

“This case and this client hold a special place in our hearts. It is cases like this that remind all of us why we became lawyers. We have been working on this case since June 2020. We have given all that we had to fight for Mr. Jones and for the rights of protesters to be free from excessive force. We are so deeply grateful for this jury verdict.”

Jones was featured as a vocalist in Glenn Kaino’s exhibition, [“In the Light of a Shadow,”](https://massmoca.org/event/glenn-kaino-in-the-light-of-a-shadow/) at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art. Please watch his incredibly moving performance of “Sunday Bloody Sunday” here:


“We have a powerful platform and we are privileged when we are able to use it to further causes we all care deeply about, like we did in the case on behalf of Deon Jones,” Marquart said.

# All The Attorneys We Lost In 2018... To Other Law Firms
## Much needed trimming or a sign of trouble?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 14, 2019 at 1:13 PMMay 14, 2019 at 12:08 PM
43
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/all-the-attorneys-we-lost-in-2018-to-other-law-firms/&text=All%20The%20Attorneys%20We%20Lost%20In%202018…%20To%20Other%20Law%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/all-the-attorneys-we-lost-in-2018-to-other-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/all-the-attorneys-we-lost-in-2018-to-other-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One of the best parts of any awards show is the annual “In Memoriam” multimedia extravaganza where an industry honors those it’s lost over the last year. The human highlight reel of accomplishments demonstrates just how much of a debt the present owes to the individuals who’ve departed.

Similarly, there are more than a few law firms looking around their offices wondering whatever happened to the star talent that once populated the halls. Law360 took stock of [the firms most ravaged by attrition](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1159070/the-firms-that-lost-the-most-attorneys-in-2018) — mostly lateral attrition — over the last year. Consider this an “In Memoriam” for these firms watching their human capital move on.

LeClair Ryan: Attorney headcount down 18.2 percent. Partner headcount down 14.2 percent.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
If those numbers look bad, know that the equity partner numbers look worse. Law360 reports that LeClair Ryan’s equity ranks have dropped by 60 percent. Still, the firm just opened a Dallas office and seems committed to turning this crisis into an opportunity for a leaner practice. Time will tell whether or not that works out for them.

Winstead: Attorney headcount down 10.9 percent. Partner headcount down 1.9 percent.

For Winstead, the mantra might be that less is more. Even though the firm shed a number of attorneys in the ongoing assault of large national firms luring talent away from established Texas firms, Winstead posted its second-highest profits ever last year.

Knobbe Martens: Attorney headcount down 10.8 percent. Partner headcount down 7.2 percent.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
Intellectual property law in America may be a mess overall, but one of its successes over the last few years is the advent of the PTAB process to streamline patent disputes. Unfortunately, this does put a dent in the need for armies of patent attorneys.

Lathrop Gage: Attorney headcount down 9.5 percent. Partner headcount down 11.4 percent.

Don’t let the numbers fool you, this firm is in growth mode, having expanded in Boston and Los Angeles and having added a Dallas office this year. It just happens to be that the losses have outpaced the growth over the last four years. Still, with revenue up, Lathrop might be getting the better end of the flow.

Jenner & Block: Attorney headcount down 9.1 percent. Partner headcount down 13.8 percent.

From Jenner’s perspective, 2018 was the exception that proves the rule. Beyond the snapshot of last year, the firm’s been growing and even expanded internationally in 2018 — something not captured by the U.S. headcount numbers.

# With Layoffs Looming, Associate Lateral Moves Have Practically Flatlined
## Biglaw's got some overcapacity problems.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 3, 2023 at 12:44 PMAugust 3, 2023 at 11:57 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/with-layoffs-looming-associate-lateral-moves-have-practically-flatlined/&text=With%20Layoffs%20Looming,%20Associate%20Lateral%20Moves%20Have%20Practically%20Flatlined)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/with-layoffs-looming-associate-lateral-moves-have-practically-flatlined/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/with-layoffs-looming-associate-lateral-moves-have-practically-flatlined/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As layoffs continue to plague Biglaw firms this summer, has anyone stopped to wonder why? Back in June, [Kate Reder Sheikh](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/kate-reder-sheikh), a legal recruiter for Major, Lindsey & Africa, [noted](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/reed-smith-cuts-50-lawyers-and-staff-as-big-law-layoffs-continue) that some firms were facing overcapacity among their ranks [due to a lack of attrition](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/the-biglaw-layoffs-are-far-from-over/) (or “bloated payrolls,” as she put it).

Now, we have even more hard evidence on Biglaw’s overcapacity: while lateral moves for partners have neared record highs, lateral moves for associates are almost at a standstill. Paired with a decrease in demand, of course this is leading to associate layoffs.

The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/08/01/associate-lateral-moves-remain-depressed-even-as-partner-moves-bounce-back/) has additional details on these lateral woes thanks to some newly released data from Decipher Investigative Intelligence:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The second quarter of this year was the second busiest for partner moves from 2017 to 2023, with 1,265 moves, just 4% below the 1,322 moves in the second quarter of 2022, according to Decipher.

On the other hand, the data shows associate moves in the second quarter were down 43% to 2,797 from 4,904 in the same period in 2022, and down 5% compared to the six-year average from 2017 and 2023.

Overall, lateral moves in the U.S. were off 41% year-to-date, mostly due to the reduction in associate moves, though the discrepancy narrowed a bit in the second quarter, as moves were off 50% after the first quarter, according to Decipher chief data officer Greg Hamman.

So, what’s going on here? “Firms are still in the midst of rebalancing their headcounts at the associate level,” Hamman told Am Law. “Rebalancing” is a really polite way of saying that many Biglaw firms are letting associates know that they’ve overstayed their welcome.

Hopefully things will improve soon, and more associates will not only be able to feel confident enough with market conditions to make a lateral move, but to remain with their firms without fear of being laid off.

[Associate Lateral Moves Remain Depressed Even as Partner Moves Bounce Back](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/08/01/associate-lateral-moves-remain-depressed-even-as-partner-moves-bounce-back/) [American Lawyer]

# New Biglaw Ranking Alert: Presenting The Industry Pulse Top 50 Law Firms
## Did your law firm make the cut? Let's find out!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 19, 2021 at 12:12 PMOctober 19, 2021 at 11:49 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/new-biglaw-ranking-alert-presenting-the-industry-pulse-top-50-law-firms/&text=New%20Biglaw%20Ranking%20Alert:%20Presenting%20The%20Industry%20Pulse%20Top%2050%20Law%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/new-biglaw-ranking-alert-presenting-the-industry-pulse-top-50-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/new-biglaw-ranking-alert-presenting-the-industry-pulse-top-50-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s a good thing lawyers love law firm rankings, because there are tons of them. Every year, there’s a whole new crop of these rankings to obsess over. Aren’t you getting tired of them? No, of course not. Lawyers love rankings more than they love money (okay, maybe that’s taking it a step too far).

You’ve seen the [Am Law 100](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/a-deep-dive-into-the-2021-am-law-100-rankings/) ranking. You’ve seen the [NLJ 500](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-the-united-states/) ranking. You’ve seen the [ALM Global 100](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-global-100-the-richest-law-firms-in-the-world-2021/) ranking. You’ve seen the [Vault 100](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/vault-100-rankings-the-most-prestigious-law-firms-in-america-2022/) ranking. You’ve seen the [Vault Best Law Firms to Work For](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/vault-quality-of-life-rankings-the-best-law-firms-to-work-for-in-america-2022/) ranking. You’ve seen the [Working Mother Best Law Firms for Women](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/elite-firms-recognized-by-working-mother-magazine-2021/) ranking. You’ve seen the [Law360 Glass Ceiling Report](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-glass-ceiling-report-law-firms-say-they-support-women-but-are-nowhere-near-closing-the-gender-gap/) ranking. You’ve even seen the U.S. News Best Lawyers® Best Law Firms ranking.

But have you ever seen a ranking of the best law firms in the U.S. from two of Instagram’s top influencers on Biglaw associate culture? Here’s your chance.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Before we get to the [Industry Pulse Top 50 Law Firms](https://www.instagram.com/p/CVLn7O-vQjp/?utm_medium=copy_link), let’s discuss the creators of the new ranking, Biglaw meme connossieurs [Big Law Boiz](https://www.instagram.com/biglawboiz/) and [Non-Equity Partner](https://www.instagram.com/nonequitypartner/). Here’s what they say about themselves, in their own words:

Since their inception, @BigLawBoiz and @NonEquityPartner have existed primarily to entertain, distract and represent a voice of the shared experience of young professionals. In pursuit of that mission, we have been fortunate enough to use our platforms to provide much-needed transparency into an otherwise-opaque industry which has historically thrived on information asymmetry among its constituents. Our platforms grant us unparalleled access to many thousands of young lawyers across firms, practice areas, seniority levels and geographies. Our unique, personal access to associates allows us to measure the true “pulse” of the legal industry. It is a responsibility we do not take lightly.

And what is the methodology behind this new Instagram-based ranking? Here is a statement Big Law Boiz and Non-Equity Partner provided to Above the Law:

In our inaugural Industry Pulse List, which ranks the Top 50 Law Firms in the U.S., we attempt to provide visibility into the current competitive landscape of the legal industry. Our sincere hope is that this list provides our stakeholders — from practicing attorneys, to law students, to legal talent professionals — with a more clear picture of what to expect in the legal field so they can make more informed, empowered career decisions.

Our data-driven ranking methodology is a product of years of research based on user feedback, literature reviews, trends in our own data, availability of new data, reviewing other published rankings and engaging with leading industry professionals. We found that the rankings provided by traditional publications reflect a notion pervasive across the legal industry: “we do things this way because this is how it has always been done.” The same names continuously appear in more-or-less the same spots across all lists.

The Industry Pulse List seeks to reward firms that reject this mentality. The firms that saw the greatest variance from their entrenched positions among other ranking lists have demonstrated a willingness to innovate. Examples of influential factors include the adoption of legal technology, alternative fee structures like ‘flat fee,’ recognizing diversity of thought, authentic efforts to recognize and support attorneys’ mental health issues and a demonstrated commitment to attorney development. We hope the advent of this ranking system spurs law firms to adopt a more forward-thinking approach.

Congratulations to all law firms that made the inaugural Industry Pulse ranking!
